metadata.case_name: Golak Nath & Ors. v. State of Punjab & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966; Writ Petition Nos. 202 and 203 of 1966

facts.text: Henry Golak Nath died on July 30, 1953. Petitioners in Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966 are his son, daughter and grand-daughters.

Financial Commissioner, Punjab, in revision against order of Additional Commissioner, Jullundur Division, held by order dated January 22, 1962 that an area of 418 standard acres and 9 1/4 units was surplus in the hands of the petitioners under Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act X of 1953, read with s. 10-B thereof.

Petitioners filed writ under Art. 32 challenging Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951, Fourth Amendment Act, 1955, Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964 insofar as they affected fundamental rights, and s. 10-B of Punjab Act X of 1953 as void violating Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f) and (g).

Writ Petitions Nos. 202 and 203 of 1966 filed challenging Mysore Land Reforms Act (Act 10 of 1962) as amended by Act 14 of 1965, which fixed ceilings on land holdings and conferred ownership of surplus lands on tenants, as infringing Arts. 14, 19 and 31.
States of Punjab and Mysore contended that the Acts are saved by Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, amending Art. 31A and including the Acts in 9th Schedule.
In Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966, 7 parties intervened; in No. 202, one party intervened; notice to Advocates General of various States.
Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1961 (Mysore Act 10 of 1962) included as item 51 in Ninth Schedule; Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 (Punjab Act 10 of 1953) as item 54.

legal_issues.text: Validity of the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, particularly whether Parliament can amend the Constitution in a manner that injures, maims or destroys its indestructible character or abridges fundamental rights.
Whether the word 'amendment' in Art. 368 implies limits, and whether fundamental rights are part of the basic structure beyond amendment.
Whether 'law' in Art. 13(2) includes constitutional amendments made under Art. 368, rendering such amendments void if they abridge fundamental rights.
Whether previous decisions in Sankari Prasad and Sajjan Singh require reconsideration regarding amendability of fundamental rights.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Constitution is intended to be permanent and cannot be amended in a way which would injure, maim or destroy its indestructible character.
The word 'amendment' implies addition or change within the lines of the original instrument to effect improvement, not to destroy the permanent character.
Fundamental rights are part of the basic structure; power under Art. 368 can only preserve, not destroy them.
Limits on amending power implied in Art. 368; 'amend' has limited meaning, unlike 'repeal and re-enact' elsewhere.
Constituent Assembly debates, speeches of Nehru and Ambedkar, and withdrawal of Kamath amendment show amendment of Part III outside Art. 368.
Part III is self-contained code, elastic for changing situations.
Power to amend derived from implication in Art. 368, articles amended, or legislative power under Arts. 245,246,248.
'Law' in Art. 13(2) includes constitutional law; amendments abridging FR void.
17th Amendment detracts from High Court jurisdiction under Art. 226 and State legislative powers, falls under proviso to Art. 368.

respondent_arguments.text: Constitutional amendment is exercise of sovereign constituent power, partakes character of Constitution itself.
Distinction between rigid and flexible Constitution based on express limits; no implied limitations.
Art. 368 clear, unequivocal; doctrine of implied limitations rejected by American courts.
Amending clause enables Parliament to express will of people per changing events; restrictions lead to revolution.
No basic and non-basic features; everything amendable for growth.
Constituent Assembly debates not for construing Art. 368; nothing excludes FR from amendment.
Amendments from political necessity, not judicial questions.
Art. 368 clear; Art. 13(2) admits qualifications; Art. 13(2) cannot control Art. 368.
Amendments enforce Directive Principles; reversal causes economic chaos.
Art. 31A and 9th Schedule do not affect Art. 226 or State powers; not under Art. 368 proviso.

court_reasoning.text: Fundamental rights given transcendental position, beyond reach of Parliament; Part III and IV integrated scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fundamental rights are primordial, natural rights necessary for human personality.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 368 prescribes procedure for amendment; power to amend is legislative power under Arts. 245-248, subject to Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amendment is 'law' within Art. 13(2); includes constitutional law.

court_reasoning.text: Sankari Prasad and Sajjan Singh reconsidered; 'law' in Art. 13(2) includes amendments; prior decisions turned on erroneous assumption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Three judges in Sajjan Singh doubted Sankari Prasad; conflict resolved here.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment process follows legislative procedure (bill, passage, assent); internal evidence shows amendment is law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arts. 4, 169, Schedules confirm amendments by legislative process.

court_reasoning.text: No sovereign amending power overriding limitations; courts can review if within scope.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Political questions not excluded; jurisdiction depends on exclusion.

court_reasoning.text: 'Amendment' cannot destroy basic structure, but narrower basis: cannot abridge FR.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Declines to decide on non-Part III structure.

court_reasoning.text: 17th Amendment void under Art. 13(2) as it abridges FR; prospective overruling to avoid chaos.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Past amendments and laws validated; future amendments cannot abridge FR.

holdings.text: Parliament has no power to amend Part III so as to abridge fundamental rights; amendments are 'law' under Art. 13(2) and void to that extent.
Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, void insofar as it takes away or abridges fundamental rights.
Decision has prospective operation only; prior amendments and laws not affected retrospectively.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Parliament could amend Part III; turned on 'law' in Art. 13(2) excluding constitutional law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld 17th Amendment; minority doubted Sankari Prasad on Art. 13(2).
Legislature could amend constitution by ordinary process if empowered.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Bribery Commissioner v. Pedrick Ranasinghe
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature must follow conditions in instrument regulating its power.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. Gopalan v. State of Madras

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 13(2) voids laws abridging FR, including amendments; Art. 368 procedure for amendment; Art. 31A/B protect land laws but challenged via 17th Amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Declared surplus land; included in 9th Schedule by 17th Amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixed ceilings, conferred ownership on tenants; included in 9th Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended Art. 31A definition of 'estate'; added Acts to 9th Schedule; held void for abridging FR.

outcome.summary: The Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 held void under Art. 13(2) insofar as it abridges fundamental rights; decision prospective only, validating prior amendments and land reform laws; writ petitions allowed to that extent without disturbing settled rights.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that 17th Amendment invalid re fundamental rights; no retrospective invalidation of past laws.

key_quotes.text: "The fundamental rights are given a transcendental position under our Constitution and are kept beyond the reach of Parliament."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on immutability of fundamental rights.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion, the expression 'amendment of the Constitution' plainly and unambiguously means amendment of all the provisions of the Constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Sajjan Singh, contrasted with overruling view.

key_quotes.text: "A fundamental right should be looked upon... as something that you want to make permanent in the Constitution."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Nehru's speech emphasizing permanence of FR.

key_quotes.text: "Now, what is it we do? We divide the articles... If the future Parliament wishes to amend any particular article which is not mentioned in Part III..."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Ambedkar distinguishing FR from amendable parts.
